ROHM AND HAAS CHEMICALS LLC - KNOXVILLE SITE

EPA Risk Management Plan (RMP) Executive Summary



INTRODUCTION 



The Rohm and Haas Chemicals LLC Knoxville site is a manufacturing facility located in Knoxville, Tennessee.  Rohm and Haas first came to Tennessee in 1943 as part of the national defense effort in World War II.  In a government-owned facility, the company began production of Plexiglas acrylic sheet for use in American military aircraft.  Following the war, Rohm and Haas purchased the Knoxville facility and expanded its production capabilities to include acrylic polymers.

Although no longer a Plexiglas manufacturer, the Knoxville site employees approximately 220 personnel and produces over 150 different products which are sold to other manufacturers who use them as key components in consumer products such as paints, laundry detergents, paper coatings, and non-woven binders.



The site contributes to a variety of charitable organizations within the community and works closely with its Community Advisory Panel (CAP) to identify and address needs and community concerns.



We are pleased to provide information on our safety and emergency preparedness plans, as well as the systems and training at Rohm and Haas designed to prevent accidental releases.



THE EPA RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM



In a series of rules promulgated between 1994 and 1998, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency established the Risk Management Program (RMP) under Clean Air Act Section 112(r).  The RMP contains a list of toxic and flammable chemicals.  Facilities that manage more than a threshold amount of a listed chemical may be subject to the RMP.  Covered facilities must assess the risks associated with their management of the listed chemicals and produce a plan to prevent releases and incidents.  In order to assist in emergency planning, covered facilities must evaluate "worst case" and "alternative case" scenarios that would result from the release of a listed chemical.  Finally,

the covered facility must make their risk management program available to the public.  This summary is part of the Rohm and Haas Chemicals LLC Knoxville site's communication effort.



REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The RMP regulated chemicals used by the site in the manufacture of acrylic polymers are Acrylonitrile and Aqueous Ammonia (~30% Ammonia in Water).   Each chemical is listed as an RMP toxic chemical.  Acrylonitrile is a raw material that is chemically combined to form acrylic polymers.  Aqueous Ammonia is used as a neutralizer to adjust the pH of polymers.  



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY 



The Rohm and Haas Chemicals LLC Knoxville site has a long standing commitment to providing a safe workplace and implementation of procedures and practices to prevent accidental releases.  This commitment is clearly stated in the site Environmental, Health, and Safety (EH&S) policy: 



- EH&S considerations are as important as production and operational concerns when decisions in these areas are required.



- We will provide a secure workplace free of unacceptable risk to our employees, our community, and the environment.  



- We are committed to compliance with all relevant EH&S regulations and standards, including the American Chemistry Council Responsible Care?Y Guiding Principles and Codes.



- We will provide our employees with the necessary training, information, and equipment to work safely and in an environmentally acceptable manner.



- Each employee will be responsible and accountable for working safely and protecting the environment.



- We will have emergency response and contingency plans in place to address potential incidents.



- We will provide opportunities for each employee to participate in the process of continually improving our EH&S performance.



- We will provide programs to assist employees in maintaining good health.



- We will manage our emissions, discharges, and wastes so as to minimize or eliminate har

mful effects to the community or the environment.



- We will require our contractors to meet the same level of EH&S performance as we do ourselves.



Under this policy, we maintain emergency response procedures and equipment to minimize hazards to human health or the environment from fires, explosions, or any unplanned release of hazardous materials.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS 



The Knoxville site maintains a number of accident prevention programs in order to ensure safe operation of all processes.  The site complies with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) rule, which is nearly identical to EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) rule. Additionally, the site follows corporate and site-specific safety standards (which in some cases are more stringent than the OSHA general safety standards) while also complying with other applicable Federal, State, and Local regulations and standards.  The following items are part of our ongoing program to prevent releases and incidents for RMP chemicals as well as any other chemicals:  



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION:  Employees are involved in many activities to continuously improve site EH&S performance.   Participation includes, but is not limited to, audits, design and pre-startup safety reviews, process hazard analysis, training, procedure development, incident investigations, and various site teams.



PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS:  Various process hazard analysis techniques are used to identify and analyze the potential hazards associated with chemicals and processes. Corrective action plans are developed and implemented as part of the analyses.  Updates occur at least every five years.  Safety systems are designed into the processes.  These are designed to create several layers of protection, such that, if one system fails, other systems will maintain the process in a safe state.  Examples of these engineering and administrative controls include, but are not limited to:



- Red

undant safety systems and instrumentation

- Automatic shutdown devices that are triggered if critical safety equipment malfunctions

- Secondary containment for storage tanks

- Alarm systems and automatic shutdown devices for critical control parameters

- Pressure relief devices to prevent overpressurization

- Fire protection systems

- Comprehensive written procedures and training programs

- Operator surveillance of unloading operations

- Safety permit system to control work in hazardous areas

- Preventative maintenance program for equipment

- Extensive Management of Change (MOC) program

-    Controlled entry to site



OPERATING PROCEDURES:  Operating procedures have been developed for all processes to ensure safe operation.  Employees that operate the manufacturing process are included in the development, training, and periodic review of these procedures.   Our processes are ISO 9000 certified. 



EMPLOYEE TRAINING:  Training programs have been developed and implemented to ensure that all affected employees understand the hazards of the chemicals used and the required safe handling procedures. Employees involved in operating the manufacturing processes are trained, tested, qualified, and certified at least once every three years as required by OSHA PSM.      



MECHANICAL INTEGRITY:  This program was established to ensure the integrity of process equipment.  Elements of this program include:



- Identification and categorization of equipment and instrumentation

- Inspections and tests

- Establishment of inspection frequencies

- Development and application of maintenance procedures

- Training of maintenance personnel

- Documentation of tests and inspection results



PRE START UP SAFETY REVIEWS:  Safety reviews of new processes, major projects, and new chemicals are conducted as part of the site Management of Change (MOC) process to ensure safe transition into the manufacturing process.  



HOT WORK PERMIT:  As part of the overall site safe work per

mit (SWP) system, the hot work program/permit manages welding, cutting, brazing and other ignition sources throughout the site to prevent fires and explosions.



MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE (MOC):  This procedure is in place to properly manage the changes involving processes, chemicals, technology, people, equipment or facilities to ensure that those changes do not present unacceptable risk.



CONTRACTOR TRAINING AND SAFETY REVIEWS:  Contractors are evaluated to ensure they have the appropriate job skills, knowledge, training, and certification to perform their assigned work safely.  The safety performance of contractors is periodically reviewed.   We require our contractors to meet the same level of EH&S performance as site employees.



INCIDENT INVESTIGATION:  Any incidents or near misses involving the release of hazardous materials are investigated by a team of skilled and knowledgeable personnel.  These investigations identify corrective actions, evaluate our management systems, and are documented and communicated as appropriate throughout the company in a narrative report.  Any required corrective actions are tracked for timely completion.



COMPLIANCE AUDITS:  Audits of our Process Safety Management System and RMP are conducted at least every three years by qualified personnel.  These audits review accident prevention activities to ensure the requirements of the programs are being met.  Any required corrective actions are tracked for timely completion.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The Rohm and Haas Chemicals LLC Knoxville site has had no accidental releases of Acrylonitrile or Aqueous Ammonia in the past five years which resulted in deaths, injuries, significant on-site property damage, evacuations, sheltering in place, off-site property damage, or environmental damage.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The site maintains an up-to-date emergency response plan (ERP) which is coordinated with local responders and the Local Emergency Management Agency. The ERP ha

s been designed to meet the requirements of all relevant regulations requiring emergency response plans, and is intended to prevent and mitigate the consequences of a hazardous material spill, protect the well-being of Rohm and Haas employees, the surrounding community, and the environment, and serve as a reference to responders in the event of an emergency.  Copies of the response plan have been provided to and are coordinated with the local Police and Fire Departments, a local hospital, and the local and state Emergency Management Agencies.  



A trained on-site incident commander (Emergency Response Leader) is assigned the responsibility of coordinating the site response to any incident which may occur, including communicating response needs with the local responders.  A trained incident commander is on duty 24 hours per day.  



A drill schedule is developed annually which includes at least one evacuation drill and other drills which test the primary components of our plan (e.g., chemical shelter in place, severe weather, etc.)  Alarm systems are also periodically tested.  All personnel are trained on the relevant aspects of the ERP.  



WORST CASE AND ALTERNATIVE CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS 



The RMP rule provides detailed requirements that define a worst case scenario, namely a release of the entire contents of the largest storage vessel occurring under very stable weather conditions and at a low wind speed.  EPA notes that the worst case scenario is designed principally to support a dialogue between the source and the community on release prevention, and not to serve as the sole or primary basis for emergency planning.  Based on previous site history, in addition to the several layers of protection in place, the worst case scenarios is highly unlikely to actually occur.



The site worst case scenario is documented and is based on the detailed requirements for worst case scenarios as prescribed by the RMP rule.



The RMP rule also defines the alternative rel

ease scenario.  Unlike worst case scenarios, the alternative release scenario can be limited by active mitigation and safeguards, such as alarms, automatic shutdowns, and operator interventions.  According to EPA, the alternative release scenario is a more useful communication tool for the public and first responders for emergency response preparedness and planning.



The site alternative case scenarios were chosen after review of the spill history, process hazard analyses, and discussions regarding potential scenarios with knowledgeable and experienced operating personnel.  The identified scenarios are more credible than the worst case scenario, but remain unlikely due to the design of equipment, implementation of prevention programs, and training of our personnel.



 

CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



It is our belief that effective EH&S systems must be continually improved.  We constantly strive to recognize areas for improvement and implement the changes necessary to achieve our goals.  Methods used to identify areas for improvement include, but are not limited to:



- Process hazard analyses for manufacturing processes

- Internal audits of procedures and processes

- Site inspections

- Observations of "on-the-floor" work 

- Review of completed safe work permits and other procedures

- Safety suggestion and near miss program



In addition, the following are examples of safety improvement opportunities identified and implemented by the site for an RMP covered chemical.



- Installation of secondary containment around tank truck unloading area to catch material in the event of a spill

- Conversion from bottom tank truck unloading to top unloading to reduce the potential for spills

- Installation of a sealless pump to reduce the likelihood for leaks

- Installation of a backflow prevention device in unloading piping

- Restriction of traffic under piping to prevent a collision

- Replacement of transfer piping



Improvements made since the 2014 RMP submittal

include:



- Installation of a containment pit to hold additional material and fire fighting water in the event of a spill

- Key control system to ensure material is unloaded to correct tank

- Additional fencing to prevent unintended access or traffic when offloading

- Additional procedures to ensure the receipt of the proper materials from suppliers



Project plans in place for an RMP chemical include:



- Improved process controls

- Area chemical detectors



The site will continue to implement other safety improvement opportunities as they are identified.
